Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Wisconsin (UW) - Madison CEMRI is founded on a network of national and international collaborations that will simultaneously tackle global challenges in materials research and engineering, bring new international perspectives to the materials educational environment, benefit regional Midwest and national institutions, and form regional alliances that will transcend individual research areas and vastly advance the climate for materials research and education throughout the Upper Midwest. The CEMRI unites a wide array of researchers all focused on the central theme of "Structured Interfaces."

The proposed CEMRI is organized into three interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs) and an interdisciplinary education group (IEG). Their activities are summarized as follows:

IRG 1: New Semiconductors from an Unstable World explores the creation of new multi-element compounds and semiconductor materials by gaining a fundamental understanding of the effects of strain, dimension, and flexibility on their phase behavior, stability, defect nucleation and properties.

IRG 2: Molecular and Electronic Dynamics at Organic-Inorganic Interfaces develops and applies a fundamental understanding of charge transport near and across interfaces between organic and inorganic materials. It does so through state-of-the-art probes of electronic transport and structural dynamics, theory, device fabrication and the development of new interfaces.

IRG 3: Functional Liquid Crystalline Assemblies, Materials and Interfaces designs, synthesizes and processes new classes of functional liquid crystalline materials (LCs), composites and interfaces. It does so through strategies that fuse the design of multifunctional polymers and mesogens with studies of confinement and dynamic ordering of molecular assemblies at interfaces of soft anisotropic materials.

The CEMRI has been conceived in a manner that enables each IRG and the IEG to function in a self-sufficient manner. With a combination of UW and several non-UW participants, each IRG represents a small network embedded in the regional and international hub defined by the CEMRI. However, a common interest in the fundamental physics and chemistry of interfaces and their application in devices, including their preparation, characterization and theoretical description, provides a natural connection between the IRGs.

The UW CEMRI also includes an Interdisciplinary Education Group (IEG) that plays an integral role in the center's mission. Amongst a variety of products, the IEG produces instructional aids that bring the excitement of cutting-edge research to diverse audiences. Kits produced by the UW CEMRI are based on the center's research, and serve to illustrate the importance of materials science and engineering and its role in solving grand challenges facing society in the 21st century. The CEMRI also distributes content on its IEG website, which it makes available to the public at no cost. The CEMRI's Research Experiences for Undergraduates and Research Experiences for Teachers programs help ensure that diverse groups of technically able students are attracted to careers in materials science and engineering.

The CEMRI also supports and operates state-of-the-art materials characterization facilities that serve as a focal point for materials research throughout the Upper Midwest region. The center is a participant in the Materials Facilities Research Network (MFRN), whose goal is to expand access to world-class instrumentation to users throughout the nation.

* a NSF Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC)

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Materials Research Science and Engineering Center at the University of Wisconsin - Madison (UW MRSEC) functioned as the hub of a vibrant materials network that successfully integrated partners from nine US universities to explore a wide array of materials platforms, including complex semiconductors, glasses, liquid crystals and polymers.  The research of the Center led to fundamental insights into important new classes of inorganic semiconductors that could not previously be synthesized, the design of stimuli-responsive liquid crystalline materials that were inspired by studies of bacteria, and organic glasses that were found to be far more stable than previously reported glasses.  The efforts of the Center also yielded important advances related to energy and electron transfer processes that occur at critical interfaces of electronic and photonic devices.  These discoveries and many others were disseminated through >560 peer-reviewed publications. Over the grant period, UW MRSEC research also generated knowledge that led to 35 patent applications, 18 issued patents and 11 licensed patents.  A network of collaborations with industry and national laboratories, including 67 international research collaborations, was nucleated by the Center.

To broaden further its impact, the UW MRSEC integrated the discovery and creation of knowledge with international programs, professional development opportunities, efforts to broaden participation, creation of shared instrument facilities, industry outreach, and dissemination through informal education programs and state-of-the-art educational materials. The Center maximized synergy between education and research, as evidenced by the creation and distribution of a broad range of research-inspired educational products (online video lab manuals, kits, presentations and publications) that built on the UW MRSEC's materials science discoveries and expertise.  These educational outputs were widely adopted for K-12 and college-level instruction, and disseminated broadly through strategic partnerships.  In addition, large-scale events such as Science Saturdays and Engineering Expo reached thousands of individuals, and served to excite the public about science and engineering and its potential to change the world.  Overall, the UW MRSEC's education and outreach programs and products impacted more than 1 million individuals during the grant period. The Center also hosted a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, which served as an important source of diversity in the graduate student population (78% of REU participants continued to graduate school). The Center leveraged its partnership with University of Puerto Rico to hold a highly productive Research Experience for Teachers (RET) program with a unique cross-cultural emphasis achieved by giving teachers from Puerto Rico and Wisconsin an opportunity to interact while developing cutting-edge, culturally relevant, educational materials. At a local level, the UW MRSEC irreversibly transformed the landscape and attitude at the UW for students and faculty from underrepresented groups, and it served as a model to the entire UW community of the effectiveness of fully integrated research, education, outreach, industrial and diversity programs.

The research of the UW MRSEC was fundamental in nature.  The UW MRSEC, however, strived to bring the products of its research to applications that benefit society and create jobs. The research of the UW MRSEC, for example, is now finding application in new technology for high-speed electronics, sensors, and solar cells.   Research on glass science, which includes oxides, metals, semiconductors, polymers, and small molecules, is finding numerous applications ranging from telecommunications to structural materials to bio-preservation. Research on liquid crystals is leading to new classes of chemical and biological sensors that are exquisitely sensitive. These efforts were advanced, in part, by the spinning out of new companies from the Center.  The Center's industrial consortium, with 25 member companies, played a leadership role in the creation of a new Regional Materials and Manufacturing Network that now connects 9 campuses of the University of Wisconsin system and 28 industrial affiliates that promote sharing of facilities and regional economic growth.  Annually, the MRSEC's Share Instrument Facilities (SIF) served more than 160 principal investigators covering >550 individual users in 8 schools/colleges and 55 departments at UW-Madison. Total yearly uses exceeded 59,000, representing 88,000 usage hours, including by companies, other universities and researchers from national laboratories.
